title: The story behind the Boston Tea Party - Ben Labaree

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for the American colonists' opposition to the British taxation on tea?

options.label: A
options.text: They did not like the taste of British tea.

options.label: B
options.text: They had no say in tax decisions made in London.

options.label: C
options.text: They wanted to support the East India Company.

options.label: D
options.text: They preferred to drink coffee instead.

multiple-choice.question: How did the American colonists initially respond to the British taxation on tea?

options.label: A
options.text: They paid the taxes without complaint.

options.label: B
options.text: They boycotted the importation of tea from Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: They smuggled tea from other countries.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not drink tea at all.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The British government sent more troops to enforce tax collection.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To lower the price of tea to consumers.

options.label: C
options.text: To prohibit the smuggling of tea.

options.label: D
options.text: To grant independence to the American colonies.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Boston Tea Party?

options.label: A
options.text: The British government repealed the taxes on tea.

options.label: B
options.text: The American colonists were forced to compensate the East India Company for the tea.

options.label: C
options.text: The port of Boston was closed until the locals compensated the East India Company for the tea.

options.label: D
options.text: The American colonies were granted independence.

title: What is verbal irony? - Christopher Warner

multiple-choice.question: What is verbal irony?

options.label: A
options.text: When a speaker says exactly what they mean

options.label: B
options.text: When a speaker says the opposite of what they mean

options.label: C
options.text: When a speaker is being sarcastic

options.label: D
options.text: When a speaker is being honest

options.label: A
options.text: Verbal irony is when a speaker says the opposite of what they mean, while sarcasm is when a speaker is being honest

options.label: B
options.text: Verbal irony is when a speaker says the opposite of what they mean, while sarcasm is when a speaker says the opposite of what they mean with a hint of mocking or attitude

options.label: C
options.text: Verbal irony is when a speaker is being sarcastic, while sarcasm is when a speaker says the opposite of what they mean

options.label: D
options.text: Verbal irony is when a speaker is being honest, while sarcasm is when a speaker says the opposite of what they mean

options.label: D

title: Dark matter: How does it explain a star's speed? - Don Lincoln

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected motion of stars at different distances from the center of a galaxy, according to Newton's physical principles and the observed mass of the galaxy?

options.label: A
options.text: Stars close to the center move quickly, while those farther away move slowly.

options.label: B
options.text: Stars close to the center move slowly, while those farther away move quickly, then slowly again.

options.label: C
options.text: Stars at all distances from the center move at the same speed.

options.label: D
options.text: Stars close to the center move quickly, while those farther away move at an unpredictable speed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the surprising observation made by scientists when measuring the speed of stars in galaxies?

options.label: A
options.text: The stars closer to the center of the galaxy moved faster than predicted.

options.label: B
options.text: The stars farther away from the center of the galaxy moved slower than predicted.

options.label: C
options.text: The stars closer to the center of the galaxy behaved as predicted, but those farther away moved faster than predicted.

options.label: D
options.text: The stars at all distances from the center moved at the same speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the previously unknown kind of matter that scientists believe explains the observed motion of stars in galaxies?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark energy

options.label: B
options.text: Dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: Invisible matter

options.label: D
options.text: Gravitational matter

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of dark matter that distinguishes it from regular matter?

options.label: A
options.text: It is visible to visible light and all other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is affected by gravity, but it is invisible to visible light and all other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not affected by gravity and is invisible to visible light and all other forms of electromagnetic radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only visible to certain forms of electromagnetic radiation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the dark matter hypothesis in the scientific community?

options.label: A
options.text: It has been directly observed and proven to be true.

options.label: B
options.text: It has been ruled out as a possible explanation for the observed motion of stars in galaxies.

options.label: C
options.text: It is still a topic of research and debate, but most scientists believe it is likely to be real.

options.label: D
options.text: It is no longer considered a relevant research question in physics.

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: 2 million
